job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Kenosha, WI
pros:
* taught life skills on how to handle poor and unprofessional management 
* some of the employees outside the department are fabulous individuals
cons:
* unprofessional and poor management 
*poor pay (unless you are friends with your manager, then you will get a 5 star rating every year and a bonus)
* you will only move up in the company if you are best friends with a manager/VP, regardless of skillset 
* micromanaging 
* doesn't care about the employee or their family (i.e. if you are sick they will ask when you will be in/how will you make up your work, not how you are doing)
 * management will talk behind your back to other employees in the department who are not of management level

job_title: RN BSN in Pleasant Prairie, WI

pros: flexible, ability for raise, on the job training

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Pleasant Prairie, WI
pros: Very fulfilling and rewarding job
cons: No work/life balance High school drama mentality within the department Low pay Little support from charge

job_title: Patient Access Representative in Kenosha, WI
pros: Good coworkers, cafeteria, PTO , schedule, ability to transfer to different departments and/or positions.
cons: I have never seen such nepotism in my life. Unqualified people promoted to management if they are family. They keep renewing contract of a select few doctors that should not be practicing. The almighty dollar rules and is king, while employees are treated like they don’t matter. They don’t pay people what they are worth and certainly not industry average. Aurora pays significantly more for all positions,

job_title: Department Assistant in Pleasant Prairie, WI
pros: They strive for functionality. They try their best to keep things running smoothly. The patients are typically the sweetest most understanding people.
cons: Theyre truly a bunch of chickens with their heads cut off. i've only been here for a year but had the opportunity to view this from two different positions with access to coworkers who we VPs down to entry level. The overall verdict was the same: they overwork you and the CEO feels $20 Piggly Wiggly gift card is an incentive for working as hard as the medical staff does. it's insulting. Security is rude and focused more on where employees park but send texts about "how annoying the patients are" and calling them lazy. The upper management works their managers to the bone where it significantly affects their health. For example, department managers get heart attack work ups because they work non-stop through the pandemic and once, they take a vacation for themselves (after a full two years of no vacations) the stressed manager is guilted into shortening it. Or biased schedulers favoring their friends, giving holidays off to the people they like and working new employees when there is supposed to be a rotation in place. Once these things are brought to HR or directors lower-level employees are brushed off and treated with such dismissal they just quit because of exhaustion. How about being an employee of the hospital where you are forced to get medical work done because the company insurance only works at the Froedtert system and the OBGYN staff won't pay you any mind or discuss any concerns. What about catching a bacterial infection from the Post Op team. Or getting bruised and battered during surgery? Or the primarily white staff photos being shared on the employee portal when a huge number of staff is not white. It's a joke.

pros: Relatively short drive with no need to take the interstate
cons: I had 5yrs experience and my current salary at Aurora was rated in the lowest 11% at $30/hr. I was looking for a raise. In the interview, my base rate was scoffed at by the manager as much, much too high for my experience, and she shook her head at me. I flat out said I wasn't taking the role unless they added $5. She became angry. Prior to that she described the role as M-W-F, 12h shifts. For a specialty like PACU, with call required, this manager was clueless. Later, one of my new grads at Aurora stated she started at $29.11 with 0 yrs experience. And yet Froedtert didn't want to pay above a new grad for a 5yr xp nurse. I ended up taking a float pool position at Ascension for $45/hr.

review_title: Not a good place to work
job_title: Registered Nurse in Pleasant Prairie, WI
pros: Colleagues are excellent Location Newer Hospital
cons: Upper management purely money driven. Administrators have no respect for providers. Low pay and poor benefits. High turnover

review_title: It's a good place to work, but not great.
pros:
- Decent amount of Paid time off
- Small/Medium Size Company
- Close to Downtown Kenosha
- Collaboration comes easy to the entire organization
cons:
- Company is not aligned when it comes to large changes
- Little to no opportunity for growth
- Large scale failure to embrace change
- Outdated in many aspects

pros:
As an employee of United Hospital System for almost three years, I can honestly state what a wonderful place it is to work. Each morning, I look forward to starting my day with new learning experiences and new projects to work on. I started at United Hospital System in an entry level position and have been promoted within my department. 

My first impression of United Hospital System is the friendliness of ALL staff I encountered during my orientation phase. I have since developed relationships with numerous managers, co-workers, and administrative staff. I enjoy getting to know my co-workers throughout the system and within my department. A positive atmosphere is what I enjoy each day. 

United Hospital System is a place where I feel safe, comfortable, and HAPPY each day I work. I have very open and honest communication with my direct supervisors and have the ability to bring concerns, questions, and new ideas to them at any time. The management staff at United Hospital System is very focused, driven, and willing to help ALL employees succeed and work to their full potential.

I believe numbers speak volume: to be a debt free hospital, to have over 2,000 employees, to have a a large number of employees who have been with United for over 20 years, what a great accomplishment for UHSI.

United Hospital System is a wonderful place to work, grow, and develop friendship. UHSI is a stable work environment and a company who offers growth and many opportunities to employees.

United is a place I plan to make my career home! I look forward to all the positive experiences and awesome opportunities I will be presented with.
cons: I do not have any cons.

pros: Interesting, challenging, fast paced work, able to grow a little
cons: Poor communication. Poor management. Extremely difficult to be approved for time off.

review_title: Managers overlook what is needed for patient safety and staff needs
pros: Great team of nurses and multidisciplinary team members
cons: Unsafe nurse to patient ratio's, disorganization with admissions, closing of step- down unit (which was essential for our organization) and incorporated into the CCU. Movement of patients to one floor to another (not due to medical transfer but admission needs (organizational chaos). Nurses that had worked there for several years receiving lower reviews than years past which did not make sense or have reasoning. Telemetry monitoring for another floor including the one I worked on with a lower nurse to patient ratio but higher acuity needs. Managers from the sister campus dictating patient loads without knowing how the flow of each floor is.  When the transition from United to Froedtert came, most were positive to see this change and most of the information the staff obtained was from the local news rather than directors or management. Left a bad taste for me as a valued nurse. Much turn-over had begun to occur which was unfortunate as many patients became accustomed to the same faces no longer being present.

pros: Friendly atmosphere. Small hospital feel.
cons: Upper management is garbage. No paid holidays, no extra weekend pay. Disorganized.

Many job seekers in the community are uninformed about all that United has to offer. I think it is important to work for an organization with a strong financial stability with such a long-standing community history.  United strives to be a healthcare employer of choice within the community in addition to providing exceptional care to our patients.

pros: Fair compensation for the area. Time off depends on where worked. This is a non union hospital. Seniority is a perk if you have it. Coworkers can make or break the shift, but that's true anywhere.
cons: No bonus, no retention bonus. Sometimes a restaurant gift card with x2movie tickets. Upper management: If they don't like you, they ll find a way to get rid of you. Management has their favorites. No career pathways.  Education opportunities are limited and no meaningful reimbursement /differential for extra education /certification.

review_title: A great place to begin an entry level position.
pros: Good job security, decent benefits, reasonably good pay for entry level work. UHS offers free meals to employees on several holidays and several other fun perks throughout the year. Employee Advisory Council gives an easy way for individual voices to be heard on safety concerns and etc.
cons: UHS doesn't do mass lay offs but will frequently decide not to fill open positions. This saves the company money, which is great, but contributes to high stress levels among employees.

pros: UHSI is a wonderful employer for what matters in nursing: Patient care is a priority, staffing is safe, education is supported and promoted, and the nursing leadership team is exceptional!  The environment in which you work should be a family, and nothing is more apparent for all who work here than the fact that we are family through and through!!  Been here 14 years and counting!
cons: Miss the Fall Festivals although the system is extremely generous to their employees.

review_title: Family atmosphere, lower pay than other hospitals, good place to start nursing career
job_title: Commissions Analyst in Pleasant Prairie, WI
pros: family atmosphere, good training prior to working as nurse on your own (atleast for me 2 years ago), flexible scheduling that allowed me to go on all my vacations, PTO benefits for full time, good nurse to patient ratio most of the time (4:1)
cons: Lower pay in comparison to other hospitals, very little help with tuition if furthering education,  per other staff- benefits are not that great, do not get extra pay on holidays

pros: I have been working for USHI for over 10 years; it is a great place to work; It might be a large System, however everyone knows everyone from the top down. It is like a large family. I work on the largest nursing unit at SCMCC, and I like the open door policy that my manager has, if I have a problem, no matter how small she always has time for me.
cons: I would like to see more money go towards continuing education.

pros: Friendly place to work.  Good job security.  Co-workers are great to work with as long as you don't need to work with upper management.  One of the better and larger employers in Kenosha.
cons: Upper management is an good ole boys club.  When it benefits UHS they view the company as being part of the Chicago and Milwaukee market, when not (such as for salary surveys) they limit it to Kenosha and its immediately adjacent communities.

review_title: Work to live not live to work
pros: Learned how not to be as a manager
cons: Hours ,no paid holidays , lower pay than what I’m worth, can’t make plans to see family, the schedule, playing favorites, always going for working harder instead of smarter insurance ok but deductible is ridiculous for one person

pros: Froedtert South is one of the last strong community hospital systems.  I get to come to work every day and work with great people and do something that is benefiting my community.  Many of the employee s have worked for the organization for over 15 years and it is easy to see why.  Froedtert South cares for its employees and promotes advancement.
cons: The only con is that there are not enough people to fill all of the jobs that are open for this growing organization.

review_title: Love the people I work with
pros: the unit I work on was very flexible with my personal schedule.  For the most part all the staff are very friendly and willing to help
cons:
Upper management. 
If you're a new nurse you get shafted and tend to get the harder patient assignment or always get first admission (this happens on certain floors).

pros: Love of patients, staff and doctor. Working Monday through Friday, no weekends or holidays.
cons: Wish that the hospital can accommodate employees that are desiring to further their education so that we can also grow the company. I feel that they can use their valued employees as an asset versus letting them go and working with another company. Pay and benefits are so so.

pros: Leading hospital in community...but I'm sure not for long
cons: No appreciation for employees, management plays favorites, high turn over rates for nurses. Honestly nurses work so hard for their degree to be treated the way administration treats them. The icu lost 21 nurses in a matter of 3 years. They lost a great ortho team, a great cardiologist,and a great cardiovascular surgeon due to their pride and trying to cut corners. Brag about being debt free but probably have some of the unhappiest employees

pros: The staff and management are passionate about Untied Hospital System and the care that they provide to their patients. The opportunities that are available to employees are endless and the management is always supportive to help the employees accomplish their goals.
cons: I have no cons for United Hospital System.

pros: Employees are great to work with and really care about the patients. Great locations with easy access to and from work. Expanding locations and services.
cons: Hard work is not valued by management, minions are preferred.  Culture between the two main campuses is not consistent.

pros: The employees are fantastic.  So nice and caring.
cons: All the raises, bonuses, and perks go to management and C level.  Once you have been there for a certain period of time you don't get raises anymore.  Insurance stinks.  Continues to cost more.

review_title: Another place that doesn't care about valuable employees
job_title: Supply Chain Assistant in Kenosha, WI
pros: Stable work, do not leave your job for this place. 30 were hired and in less than a year they all quit. Housekeeping are contracted out do a horrible job floors are dirty many issues
cons: Insurance is horrible,  holidays if you are scheduled off you need to use your pto, they will not pay your holiday earned must use PTO and if you work you ll get paid regular pay no x1/2

review_title: A great place on a great lake
pros: Kenosha is a tightly-knit community, and the same holds true in the workplace at Froedtert South. There is a wide array of information and knowledge to be had here.
cons: Sometimes we can spin a lot of plates at once, so to be a true subject matter expert takes quite a bit of work and dedication, which is important in any workplace.

pros:

pros: It's a paycheck. I say that because it's good to get your foot in the door for the experience, but don't you dare consider staying there for a career.
cons: Most management belittles you. HR will NOT help you. They fired the highest paid employees they put on furlough for COVID19 then posted their jobs to hire cheaper employees. Low pay. Administration does not care about you just the family members they hire.

pros: The ED staff is very helpful and the nurses there allow you to learn a lot. The SNI program is a great springboard into your nursing career.
cons: The starting nurse pay is not competitive with other Metro Milwaukee facilities. Horribly expensive benefits, it is actually better to opt out and buy from the Health Care Market Place.

pros: The patients are wonderful they are good people who have a strong sense of community in the Kenosha area. A.
cons: Lack of leadership. Charge RNs really do eat their young at this hospital. Worst job of my life- would never go back.

review_title: Really nothing to keep employees for the long term

cons: Insurance. Work load can be very slow making for long days. Varied shifts. No holiday pay. No overtime. Really no perks to the job. High turnover rate.
